ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course taught me some basic concepts about probability, Newton's method, Fermis method, and many different ways of approaching concepts in calculus without actually going through and learning how to do any concepts in calculus.
An understanding of probability, the basics of statistics
Principles of estimation to use in everyday life, probability and how to estimate area below a curve, x-intercepts.

I widened my skill set as we covered topics I have not covered in previous math courses such as Newtons Method. I also expanded my knowledge of topics I have covered in other courses such as estimations/ Eulers Method.
I have a better perspective of statistics and probability.
In this course, I developed some basic precalculus + calculus skills. I also learned how to estimate the probability of certain events in different scenarios.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course are that it is a good option for people who are bad at math to learn basic math concepts and to understand the goals of what calculus is trying to accomplish without actually doing the calculus. But, this class is definitely not for anyone with an advanced math background.

The professor was very accessible, as was the TF, so that was helpful. But the PSETs were often more challenging that anything we'd learned in class. The problems would be variations of what we'd gone over with the professor, but significantly more challenging versions, which created unnecessary stress and made it difficult to prepare for exams because we didn't know what to expect. Also the professor could be a bit disorganized at times; once she forgot her laptop on a day that several students needed to Zoom into class due to Covid isolation, so multiple students simply missed an entire class.
Strengths: lots of support, guided notes, patient instructor.
I found the psets to help me solidify concepts we learned in class. The course material could have been slightly better organized during class (sometimes a little bit hard to follow).
I think occasionally the course relied too heavily on precalculus material.

Strengths: My professor was very kind, and the classes were engaging for the most part. PSETS were also helpful to prepare for exams, as were the review sheets offered to us. 

Weaknesses: Lessons could feel a little disorganized and scattered at times. It could often be difficult to follow lessons in class, and I found myself having to do a great deal of "outside learning" (accessing separate resources like khan academy) in order to keep up. It felt impossible to completely comprehend certain concepts without support from out-of-class resources.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to anyone without a strong math background who still has to take a math class at Yale, and wants to approach calculus concepts without actually doing the calculus.

Yes, I absolutely would if you aren't STEM inclined but need a QR credit. I found it pretty satisfying to learn some math even though I'm not very good at it. Su Ji is very patient and you learn the material very thoroughly. Grading and testing is very fair and she wants you to succeed.
Yes, I believe its the best math class offered at Yale.
I would recommend this course to another student who wants to broaden their knowledge on some fundamental math concepts such as estimation. It is also great for non-stem majors.

It would depend. While I really liked my professor, and the material could be interesting/easy to handle at times, students considering this course should be prepared to have to do some outside work in order to keep up with certain parts of the curriculum.
